pullsbody:
Reverts mozilla/login.webmaker.org#395

Password Verification fails on staging.

```
2018-05-16T15:45:42.364199+00:00 app[web.1]: TypeError: Cannot read property 'saltedHash' of undefined
2018-05-16T15:45:42.364201+00:00 app[web.1]: at Object.compare (/app/app/db/models/index.js:504:42)
2018-05-16T15:45:42.364202+00:00 app[web.1]: at /app/app/http/controllers/user3.js:147:22
2018-05-16T15:45:42.364204+00:00 app[web.1]: at callbacks (/app/node_modules/express/lib/router/index.js:164:37)
2018-05-16T15:45:42.364205+00:00 app[web.1]: at _combinedTickCallback (internal/process/next_tick.js:131:7)
2018-05-16T15:45:42.364207+00:00 app[web.1]: at process._tickDomainCallback (internal/process/next_tick.js:218:9)

```
Will update description when i get a sec. One major change I made was I removed js beautifier because it was breaking everything. I thought we don't really need it but let me know if we do.

pullsbody: New Relic is basically a software analytics company, I guess we used some of their services a while back but no longer do so, which means we can get rid of the library and references.

pulltitle: Replace bcrypt library with bcrypt.js, Closes #386
pullsbody:
I reviewed the method structure for our current usage of bcrypt and cross-checked it with the method structures for bcrypt.js and it's basically a drop and replace solution. If someone could review this and ensure everything is functioning properly, that'd be great.

I'm filing a separate PR to remove the redundant New Relic references, I wanted to keep this PR as simple as possible and only include the changes relevant for it to function properly.

pulltitle: Replace bcrypt library with bcrypt.js, Closes #386
pullsbody:
I reviewed the method structure for our current usage of bcrypt and cross-checked it with the method structures for bcrypt.js and it's basically a drop and replace solution. If someone could review this and ensure everything is functioning properly, that'd be great.

I'm filing a separate PR to remove the redundant New Relic references, I wanted to keep this PR as simple as possible and only include the changes relevant for it to function properly.
pull_commit_message: Attempt to fix Travis CI builds

pullsbody:
Messina is a very old dependency that hasn't been updated in years. It was built in-house by members of the production team several years ago. It's heavily broken on versions of Node 4.0 and above. This dependency doesn't reside on the Mozilla organization, so we have to drop it entirely.

This dependency causes the command ```npm install``` to fail when using Node 4.0 and above due to its dependence on ```dtrace-provider@0.2.8``` which severely breaks on newer versions of Node. The Travis CI build never failed because the node_modules directory was cached, so even after the upgrade to Node 4.0 this issue was never identified as a result of pre-built binaries being cached.
Initial pass at dockerizing login. Part of the big effort to dockerize Thimble.

fixes to sqlite3 and routes.js so that login can actually run on modern node (6+).

pull_commit_message:
[bug 972919] Cleaned up app.js

A simple refactor. See the diff for details

pulltitle: [WIP][Bug 972919] Clean up code from old Login strategy
pullsbody: This is based on [Jon Buckley's patch](https://github.com/mozilla/login.webmaker.org/pull/248), and is a work in progress.
pull_commit_message:
[bug 972919] Removed CORS logic

In the previous Login strategy, other app's views would query the Login
server directly. This required the Login server to use custom middleware to
check CORS headers sent along with each request. Since each server now
communicates with Login on behalf of their views (using webmaker-auth &
webmaker-auth-client) the CORS logic is no longer needed.

pulltitle: [WIP][Bug 972919] Clean up code from old Login strategy
pullsbody: This is based on [Jon Buckley's patch](https://github.com/mozilla/login.webmaker.org/pull/248), and is a work in progress.
pull_commit_message:
[bug 972919] Removed outdated information from the readme

The change of strategy with the login server invalidated most of
the integration steps that were listed in the README. It still
needs an update (https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=939845)
but that is outside the scope of this bug.

pulltitle: changed username lookup to explicitly inside the sign up iframe
pullsbody:
testing STR
- ensure cleared cache and cookies
- run goggles/login/webmaker localhost
- visit goggles localhost page, add localhost goggles bookmark button to bookmark bar, sign in, delete account, sign out.
- visit random non-webmaker website
- run goggles from bookmarklet
- click publish button
- sign in, fill in username, click "create" button.

**old code:** you should get an error about a missing username because the input#username element is searched for on the parent page, rather than the iframe the publish dialog is running in. (this is currently happening for goggles.mofostaging and goggles.webmaker bookmarklets)

**this patch:** things should work properly, with your username being accepted, and you getting logged in as said user.
pull_commit_message: changed username lookup to explicitly inside the sign up iframe

pulltitle: allows consecutive new users to sign up within a single tool
pullsbody:
this fix forces the new user form to always be rebuilt from scratch, instead of reusing it if it had already been built once (because we bake in the user's email address when it gets built, and reusing it means the form gets submitted with the wrong user email address).

also renamed the "newMaker" function because we had two functions doing very different things, with the same name.
pull_commit_message: allows consecutive new users to sign up within a single tool

pulltitle: Bug863749 - Create API for checking if a subdomain is free
pull_commit_message: Bug863749 - Create API for checking if a subdomain is free

pullsbody:
Alright, here we go. I rewrote things so that there's only one client app - mostly because I don't know how to make the Procfile run two instances under --dev mode on different ports. If this is possible, best way to test, rather than building two `app` instances in the code. Also, this uses the new persona system (client side) as well as stubs for the webmaker-loginapi node wrapper (server side at the consumer app). The flow is now:
- user logs in with persona
- persona okays it
- consumer app (client side) calls its own /persona/verify to effect server-side auth as well
- auth passes -> req.session.email is set locally for the consumer app.
- consumer app (client side) then asks the webmaker SSO ui code to check whether this is a new, or known maker.

[EXTRA STEPS FOR NEW MAKER]
- sleak UI slides in to get the user to come up with a webmaker subdomain. they fill it in, save, etc, flow returns to the SSO ui code where this user is now a known maker
- the SSO ui code then calls the consumer app's /user/personaEmail so that the consumer app can (server side) obtain that user's display name and set it as part of the session cookie using the webmaker-loginapi, rather than trusting the client to send a legal display name.

At this would point we _should_ have a fully authenticated user, and the locally set cookie can be used for everything.
pull_commit_message: Fix bug 860365 - added webmaker user bar

- yes it's still async - I think this is best with the problem that we have to face
- have stripped out the mongoose-validator package, on inspection I think it's a bit of a dog and looks rather poorly maintained 
- error wording is up for grabs

fix bug 863362 - adding in a model for the swear filter and using it's
contents for our inital user validation

pulltitle: [865758] Improved error handling of MongoDB connection problems
pullsbody:
Added a mongoDB healthcheck middleware, and refactored some code to allow for it in the current architecture.

Ref: https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=865758
pull_commit_message: [865758] Added a database healthcheck middleware by refactoring the Mongoose handler and the user model, and modifying the architecture slightly to allow this new approach

pulltitle: [bug-866646] Bringing the webmaker nav into the login app
pullsbody:
To help us package stuff up and integrate it onto our sites this feels like a good thing to do.

Currently have ripped the CSS from @k88hudson prototype off and into here - when we land the proper styles we delete what we have in nav.css and replace with the good stuff.

pulltitle: [bug-861360] Displaying the signed in user data from the UI
pullsbody:
https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=861360

This ensures that we show the user displayname/subdomain for our users once they are signed in - something we didn't have for all use cases before.

This gives us:
- logged in users returning
- logged in users who already have a webmaker account on a secondary page
- users without an existing subdomain/displayName
pull_commit_message: [bug-861360] Displaying the signed in user data from the UI - for returning users, brand new users and currently logged in users
